utterances: Cruz is leading in recent Wisconsin polls.
A sweep here would increase the chances that Trump goes to the Republican convention without enough delegates to win outright.
In Milwaukee last night, Trump and his wife, Melania, were greeted by an unusually subdued crowd.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We did this as a quickie.
We wanted to come into this area.
We're staying here tonight.
And I know you have a baseball game and you have a big basketball game.
We're going to go really quickly tonight.
But we're going to say one thing - we're going to make America great again.
Remember that.
It was a big sports night on TV, though Trump told The Washington Post this weekend he's intentionally holding rallies at smaller venues to reduce protests.
At the rally, Tom Ross of Menomonee Falls said if Trump loses Wisconsin, the nomination will be decided at the convention.
And the establishment will try to overtake it.
I mean, it wouldn't be a choice for the American people, which is what this is all about.
It's more of a good old boy system, so...
Ohio Gov.
John Kasich is also hoping to pick up a few delegates in Wisconsin today.
It's already mathematically impossible for him to get enough delegates to win.
But Kasich is hoping that by staying in the race, he can help make it impossible for Donald Trump as well.
Sarah McCammon, NPR News, Milwaukee.
Now, polling has not always been accurate this primary season.
But for what it is worth, here's what it says.
An average of recent polls shows Ted Cruz leading Donald Trump in Wisconsin not by 10 points, as one much-publicized survey found, but certainly by several points.
On the Democratic side, an average of polls shows Bernie Sanders holding a narrow lead over Hillary Clinton.
We have been following the cease-fire in Syria and the opening it presents to aid groups to deliver desperately needed food and medical supplies.
Among them, the U.N.'s World Food Program.
WFP convoys have been able to travel to rebelled-held East Ghouta, a suburb about 10 miles outside the capital Damascus.
Human rights monitors say that despite the cease-fire the area was struck by government forces last Friday.
We reached the country director for the World Food Program in Damascus.
Jakob Kern traveled with one of those aid convoys.
Welcome.
It's good to be on the show.
How long has it been since any aid workers have been able to access the towns in East Ghouta?
The last time the U.N.
was there was in mid-2014.
So we haven't been able to reach that town, that area for more than one and a half years.
And in that time, up until you reached the area, what were the conditions for people living there?
What did you find when you got there with food and medicine?
What we found was a town that was under besiegement for many months now.
Most houses are damaged or destroyed.
People are making a living now.
It's a big area and somehow they have got used to it.
But what I really noticed is, since the cease-fire, children are actually playing outside on the park.
And that's probably the first time for a long time that they are able to do that without fear of seeing a bomb or attack.

By some accounts, the levels of benzene in the Chinese spill are 30 times what would be considered safe in the United States, levels at which the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention would advise victims to take off their clothes and seal them up in airtight plastic bags.

Clif Curtis, a toxics expert with the World Wildlife Fund, says it's likely that these health risks will linger long after the spill has passed, partly because these toxins tend to stay inside the things that eat them.
The term is called bioaccumulation, where it--as it moves up the trophic level, it resides in larger and larger quantities and can have a serious effect.
Eventually, this toxic spill will follow the river into Russia, threatening people who rely on it for food and drinking water.
Curtis says the spill will also pass through the homelands of critically endangered animals, like snow leopards and Siberian tigers.
...species that have questionable survival rates as it is in terms of low population numbers, and something like this could tip it over the edge.
The toxic slick is expected to reach Russia in about two weeks.
John Nielsen, NPR News.

Robert McCloskey was just starting his career when he wrote and illustrated the award-winning book that would become his most famous, ""Make Way For Ducklings."" The story of the Mallard family's search for a home in the wilds of Boston has won the hearts of several generations of readers and even inspired a statue in Boston's Public Garden.
This year, the book is celebrating its 75th anniversary.
NPR's Lynn Neary reports.
On an unseasonably cold and windy spring day, Dan Belich and his son, Geoffrey, headed into Boston Public Garden to the ""Make Way For Ducklings"" statue.
It's a group of small bronze ducklings happily waddling after their mother.
Dan tried to remember the names of all those little ducks.
Quack and Ack and Mack and Jack and Ack - I don't know (laughter).
Dan used to read the book to Geoffrey when he was a toddler.
They both loved the story of the duck family, who found a home on an island in the middle of the Public Garden's pond.
For them, visiting the statue is a sweet trip down memory lane.
We love coming by here to hang out with these guys - the ducks - and just, you know, pay them a visit right now and say, hello.
And I like the way they put - they put hats or scarves on them.
People often dress-up the ducks.
And on this day, shortly after Easter, they are wearing colorful bonnets.
Kids love to climb on the mother duck and pat her head - when she's not wearing a hat, that is.
Mother's head is so shiny at this point.
But she's just the right size to Pat.
That's Sal McCloskey, daughter of Robert McCloskey.
Her father, who she has always called Bob, attended art school in Boston during the 1930s.
He and a roommate had recently moved into a studio apartment in New York's Greenwich Village, when he began working on ""Make Way For Ducklings.
Bob went down to the Washington Square Market and bought a crate of ducks and brought them back to the apartment.
These ducks became part of their lives.
And Bob, in fact, used them for the illustrations for ""Make Way For Ducklings.
McCloskey's illustrations are both charming and funny.
The story of the duckling's perilous journey from the Charles River to the Public Garden through the streets of Boston has delighted readers since the book was first published in 1941.
And to celebrate its 75th anniversary, a Boston bookstore that is actually named ""Make Way for Ducklings"" held a party of its own recently.
Does anybody know what a duckling sounds like?
Quack, quack, quack.
Before listening to a reading of the book, kids got to make their own ducks with paper plates and feathers.
Are you ready?
I'm so excited.
(Unintelligible) are my favorite thing.
With their ducks in hand, the kids sat down in a circle for a reading of the book.
(Reading) Mrs. Mallard had reached the corner bookshop and turned into Charles Street with Jack, Kack, Black, Mack, Nack, Wack, Pack and Quack all marching in line behind her.
Six-year-old Grace Miller says she loves the book for one simple reason.
I just like it because I love baby ducks.
Soren Laten told his mom, Ashley, that he likes Michael, the policeman who stops traffic to help the ducks cross the street.
Why does need he need to block the traffic?
Because the ducks have to get through.
Overseeing the days events was bookstore owner Adam Hirsch, who says ""Make Way For Ducklings"" is a quintessential Boston book with a universal appeal.
It's not just parents, but it's grandparents that have grown up and loved this story, loved the ducks.
I think it gives people a warm feeling as they come and visit Boston.
Make Way For Ducklings"" was one of many classic children's books by Robert McCloskey.
But it's the only one with a statue of its own.
Lynn Neary, NPR News.
[POST-BROADCAST CORRECTION: The audio version of this story incorrectly states that Make Way for Ducklings is the only Robert McCloskey book honored with a statue.
There is a Blueberries for Sal statue in Boothbay Harbor, Maine.]
Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia once called the solicitor general's argument gobbledygook.
He deemed a majority opinion pure applesauce.
And he said he'd rather hide his head in a bag than support the court's 2015 ruling legalizing same-sex marriage.
We're taking a moment to remember Antonin Scalia, one of the most influential people who died this year.
He was a conservative hero during his 29 years on the nation's highest court, notorious for his pointed writing from the bench.
He was also known for his close friendship with fellow Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
They both enjoyed opera and rode an elephant together on a trip to India.
